1.Title: EC releases final 2021 Presidential elections results
1.Snippet: The Electoral Commission (EC) has released the final presidential election results. Overview.Summary: The 2021 Kosovan parliamentary election resulted in a landslide victory for the left-wing opposition party, Vetevendosje (Self-determination) (7,9,10). The polls closed on January 14th and the results were declared within 48 hours on January 16th (1). The extended period of political deadlock that led up to the election was a result of inconclusive elections in 2019, 2020, and 2021 (2). The next elections are scheduled for no later than 11 years after the 2021 elections (3). A map of the 2010 Kosovan parliamentary election results shows a breakdown by municipality (4). Another map shows the results of the 2019 election (6). Albin Kurti was elected as Prime Minister for a second time, after being ousted in 2020, following the landslide victory of his party (10).

Timeline.Text: The Electoral Commission releases the final results of the 2021 Kosovan presidential election.
The Vetevendosje party, led by Albin Kurti, declares victory in the Kosovan parliamentary election.
The 2019 Kosovan parliamentary election results are released, showing a landslide victory for the Vetevendosje party.
Albin Kurti is elected as Kosovo's Prime Minister for a second time.
The 2021 Kosovan parliamentary election map is released, showing the distribution of seats won by each party.

Overview.Summary: The 2021 Kosovan parliamentary election saw a landslide victory for the Vetëvendosje movement, led by Albin Kurti (4, 6, 10). The election, held on February 14, 2021, was considered to have great importance for Kosovo, Switzerland, and Europe (2). Vjosa Osmani was also a prominent figure in the election, running for MP and claiming the post of president of the country (1, 6). The largest Kosovo Serb political entity, Lista Srpska, and other parties of national minorities also ran in the election (1). The left-wing reform movement of Vetëvendosje promised justice, democracy, and rule of law (2, 7). The party's leader, Albin Kurti, extended his popularity in Kosovo by increasing the number of votes by 100% compared to the previous election in 2019 (3). The election was considered a defeat for the previous government and its supporters (3, 8, 9).

Timeline.Text: The Central Election Commission of Kosovo publishes the lists of candidates for the February 14 parliamentary elections, with Vjosa Osmani leading the list for Vetëvendosje.
The Vetëvendosje Movement, led by Albin Kurti and Vjosa Osmani, registers to run in the parliamentary elections.
The parliamentary elections take place in Kosovo, with the Vetëvendosje Movement and other parties running for office.
Vetëvendosje sees a landslide victory in the parliamentary elections, with Albin Kurti and Vjosa Osmani increasing their popularity in Kosovo.
Vetëvendosje's victory is confirmed, with the party securing 48% of the votes in the parliamentary elections.

This marks the second time Kurti has held this position, after previously being ousted from government (6). Kurti is known for his past involvement in anti-Serb demonstrations in the 1990s (1). His party won a clear majority in the early parliamentary elections held on February 14, 2021 (2, 4, 10). The election was also seen as a referendum on the future direction of Kosovo (8).

Overview.Summary: The 2021 Kosovan parliamentary election (7, 8, 9, 10) took place on February 14, 2021 (7, 8, 10) and resulted in a landslide victory for Albin Kurti's Vetëvendosje party (8, 9, 10). The National Electoral Commission announced on January 16, 2021 that the election would be held on May 31, 2021 (3). However, due to turbulent internal politics and the collapse of the previous coalition government, a snap election was called (7). The election saw the ruling Nur Otan party win 71% of the vote (1) and the military's proxy party, the Union Solidarity and Development Party, win only 33 seats (2). The election also sparked discussions about the possibility of snap parliamentary elections in Serbia in 2022 (5).

Timeline.Text: Kosovo holds a snap parliamentary election.
The Vetevendosje party wins a landslide victory in the election.
President Vjosa Osmani is elected by the parliament.
Kazakhstan holds parliamentary elections, with the ruling Nur Otan party winning by a large margin.
The National Electoral Commission of Somaliland schedules the 2021 municipal and parliamentary elections for May 31.
In Serbia, snap parliamentary elections are announced for April 3, two years earlier than originally planned.

The Central Election Commission of Kosovo publishes the lists of candidates running in the election, with Vjosa Osmani leading the Vetëvendosje list and Albin Kurti's name omitted.
The election takes place, with the Vetëvendosje Movement as one of the main contenders.
The Vetëvendosje Movement, led by Albin Kurti, wins a landslide victory in the Kosovan parliamentary election.
Vetëvendosje party leader Albin Kurti celebrates the party's victory in the election.

Overview.Summary: The 2021 Kosovan parliamentary election will take place on February 14, 2021 (1,2,3,4,5,6,9,10). The election is significant as it marks the end of an era (1,2,3) and is the fifth parliamentary election since Kosovo's declaration of independence (1,2,3,5,6). The election will involve 120 representatives with 20 mandates reserved for minority communities (1,2,3). Albin Kurti and his left-wing party, Vetevendosje, emerged as the victors in the election (7,8,10). This election follows a period of turbulent internal politics and a collapse of the previous coalition government (5,6). The election is also significant as it marks the appointment of Vjosa Osmani as the new president of Kosovo (7).

Timeline.Text: The fifth parliamentary (early) elections in Kosovo are announced for February 14, 2021.
A discussion about the upcoming election and its significance for Kosovo takes place.
The Kosovo Assembly is dissolved and a new election is called.
The snap parliamentary election takes place in Kosovo.
Vjosa Osmani is elected as the new president of Kosovo.
Albin Kurti is elected as the new prime minister of Kosovo.

Overview.Summary: The 2021 Kosovan parliamentary election is set to take place on 14 February 2021 (1,3,4,10). The leading party, Vetevendosje, is led by Albin Kurti, who previously organized demonstrations against Serbian rule in the 1990s (2). The party is expected to win by a landslide (13,15,19). Kurti has been voted in as Prime Minister for a second time (17). The election will see 120 representatives elected, with 20 reserved for minority communities (1). The largest Kosovo Serb political entity, Lista Srpska, is also running in the election (3,4,9,19). In addition, the election has sparked discussions about the country's future relationship with Serbia (19).

Timeline.Text: The fifth parliamentary (early) elections in Kosovo are scheduled for February 14, 2021.
The Electoral Commission releases the final results of the 2021 presidential election.
The Vetevendosje Movement, led by Albin Kurti, is the front-runner in the parliamentary elections.
Vetevendosje leader Albin Kurti declares victory in the Kosovo election.
Albin Kurti is elected Prime Minister of Kosovo.
The results of the 2021 parliamentary election are mapped out in municipalities.
The map of the 2021 parliamentary election results in municipalities is released.
The Kosovo parliament elects Albin Kurti as Prime Minister for the second time.
Vjosa Osmani is elected as President of Kosovo.
